Award.AwardTitle: ELT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Investigating the Biotic and Paleoclimatic Consequences of Dust in the Late Paleozoic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research:
Investigating the Biotic and Paleoclimatic Consequences of Dust in the Late Paleozoic

by

Gerilyn Soreghan, University of Oklahoma, EAR-1338331
Sarah Aciego, University of Michigan, EAR-1337440
Linda Hinnov, Johns Hopkins University, EAR-1337454
Nicholas Heavens, Hampton University, EAR-1337463

Overview
Geologic data indicate that the tropical atmosphere during the Permo-Pennsylvanian (300 Million years ago) was dust-rich. In addition, algae predominated in late Paleozoic marine ecosystems. These observations, combined with predictions from climate modeling, prompt two over-arching hypotheses driving the proposed research: 1) the unusual tropical dustiness reflects dust production by tropical upland glaciers, and 2) atmospheric dustiness fertilized marine ecosystems. Dust forces the climate system by affecting radiative forcing and atmospheric moisture, and by influencing the biosphere, but these effects are poorly known. In this research, PIs will collect data to constrain spatial (low-mid latitude) and temporal (glacial-interglacial and longer) variations in atmospheric 'dustiness,' sources of the dust, and influences between dust and ecosystem composition in order to address their over-arching hypotheses, and clarify the relationships among atmospheric dustiness, climate, and the biosphere.

Intellectual Merit
This research will reveal process links among dust, climate, and the biosphere within an icehouse, at glacial-interglacial scales. Owing to the known importance but great uncertainty of both the direct and indirect effects of dust on climate, results will expand understanding of Earth-system behavior. Tropical glaciation at low elevations implies much more widespread glaciation than currently accepted, and --if verified-- would force the community to test this hypothesis with new modeling approaches. The models to be used are identical to those used for present and future climate, and thus improvements made through the proposed work will inform modeling of Earth's climate in general. If the hypothesis that atmospheric dustiness forced marine biotic systems toward nutrient-rich conditions is confirmed, it implies a remarkably dusty Earth, and clarifies Earth-system behavior to dust-sourced fertilization. These results are relevant to growing discussions regarding geo-engineering schemes to control future climate change.

Broader Impacts
Cross-disciplinary training will occur via exchanges between geological and geochemical labs, geologists and modelers, and in joint field excursions and progress meetings. PhD students will mentor middle-school teachers through a formal summer program. Undergraduates will conduct senior theses and present at Undergraduate Research Day and national meetings. Both will interact with middle- and high-school students through a formal course on STEM education. The lead investigators will use components of the research to teach at university levels, as well as in museum, and community outreach. Ties will be established and strengthened among all participant institutions, which includes an Historically Black University, as well as international partners. This research will help ignite the research careers of three young investigators (2 with no prior NSF support). Data will be archived and shared via publications, and web-accessible tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mineral dust is increasingly recognized as critically important to understanding Earth’s climate system. Atmospheric dust exerts both direct and indirect effects on climate: directly by influencing radiative forcing (either negatively or positively, depending on composition and altitude), and indirectly by potentially fertilizing marine and terrestrial ecosystems, thereby fueling primary productivity and inducing drawdown of atmospheric CO2.

The growing recognition of these effects for the modern Earth system inspired this research to investigate the effects of atmospheric aerosols in Earth’s deep time record, and particularly the record of Earth’s last “icehouse” climate (characterized by large continental ice sheets) prior to our modern icehouse. The Late Paleozoic world of 300 million years ago captures Earth’s most recent example of an icehouse that developed on a fully vegetated planet, and Earth’s only example of icehouse collapse on a fully vegetated planet. For these reasons, it is an ideal time period to study in order to learn about forcing factors that can create such fundamental shifts in Earth’s climate, with potential application to Earth’s future.

This research focused on building and compiling the first-ever records of atmospheric dust from regions sufficiently far flung to assess global dustiness and constrain climate modeling that included a dust component for Earth’s deep-time record. Dust records were studied from outcrop and core from regions in northern and southern mid-latitudes as well as western and eastern equatorial latitudes of the Pangaean supercontinent. These records enabled assessment of glacial and interglacial records of atmospheric dustiness and demonstrate that glacials were globally dusty times. These records in turn provided constraints on climate models for this interval. Auxiliary work funded by this project also enabled investigations of the origin of loess and dust deposits (and implications for paleoclimate reconstructions), the effects of explosive volcanism on climate and the biosphere, and tests of the controversial hypothesis of glaciation in equatorial Pangaea. 

Key discoveries include:

1— The prevalence of dust overall, and cyclic shifts in dust loading during this interval support the hypothesis that much of this dust was generated by glacial processes, implying glaciation that extended beyond the traditionally accepted glaciated regions of the southern paleopole. This in turn requires a major revision of climate models for Earth’s penultimate icehouse. This conclusion is further buttressed by work funded in part by this project that indicates probable preservation of a (formerly) glaciated paleovalley at the paleoequator.

2— The mineral aerosols of the late Paleozoic are replete with reactive iron, a key micronutrient that fuels primary production. This implies that mineral dust exerted large and significant effects on the biosphere, playing a substantial role in sequestration of atmospheric CO2. The reasons for the remarkably high reactivity of iron in these dust deposits remains under investigation, as they are highly enriched compared to modern and recent mineral dust aerosols. Understanding this has significant bearing on geoengineering schemes designed to stimulate primary productivity on a future Earth.

3— Our (first-ever global compilation indicates that) The incidence of explosive volcanism from 400-200 million years ago (an interval encompassing the late Paleozoic icehouse, together with ice-free times before and after) peaked during the icehouse interval, and includes especially large volcanic centers in equatorial Pangaea and mid-high-latitude Australia. Modeling indicates an especially strong effect on the climate of the time, from direct (negative) radiative forcing of volcanic aerosols. There might have been additional effects on the biosphere. This is potentially a natural-earth example of the effect of prolonged explosive volcanism on climate (somewhat analogous to what might be proposed for solar radiation management— SRM), with attendant auxiliary effects that should be considered in any real-world attempt of SRM.

This work has resulted in (to date) the following outcomes from the University of Oklahoma group: 10 papers published in the scientific literature, another 6 in review, and over 35 abstracts presented at scientific conferences, with over 18 students as authors or coauthors. Additionally, This grant funded or partially funded 6 MS theses and 2 PhD dissertations (and all have been either published or are in submission, review, or preparation for publication). Many students involved in some way in this work come from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Hence, this research has contributed significantly to education of our STEM workforce. This work has been featured in podcasts, and in news outlets for the lay audience.
